facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 to 56 of 1957 by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated November 21, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 to 56 of 1957. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1956, of the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Appeals arise from Sessions Case No. 27/111 Sessions 1955, judgment dated June 1, 1956 by Additional Sessions Judge for Greater Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeals Nos. 861-864 of 1956 arising out of the judgment and order dated June 1, 1956, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge for Greater Bombay at Bombay in Sessions Case No. 27/111 Sessions 1955.

facts.text: Four appellants convicted: Sardul Singh Caveeshar (Appeal 53), Parmeshwar Nath Kaul (54), Vallabhdas Pulchand Mehta (55), Charucharan Guha (56).

anchor.surface_text: All of them except Jhaveri were found guilty, appellants in Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 54, Sardul Singh Caveeshar and Parmeshwar Nath Kaul, by a majority verdict and appellants in Criminal Appeals Nos. 55 and 56, Vallabhdas Pulchand Mehta and Charucharan Guha, by an unanimous verdict.

facts.text: Sentences: Caveeshar RI 3 years fine Rs.2500; Kaul RI 5 years fine Rs.5000; Mehta RI 5 years fine Rs.5000; Guha RI 3 years fine Rs.2500.

anchor.surface_text: The verdicts- of the jury were accepted by the Sessions Judge who sentenced the appellants as follows Appellant Sardul Singh Caveeshar to rigorous imprisonment for three years and a fine of Rs. 2,500. Appellant Parmeshwar Nath Kaul to rigorous imprisonment for five years and a fine of Rs. 5,000.

facts.text: Charges: Conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust of Jupiter General Insurance Co. Ltd. funds from December 1, 1948 to January 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: on charges of companyspiracy to companymit criminal breach of trust of the funds of the Jupiter General Insurance Co. Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as the Jupiter  and in pursuance of the said companyspiracy of having companymitted criminal breach of trust

facts.text: Plan to acquire controlling block of Jupiter shares (about 63,000 shares) using Jupiter's own funds.

anchor.surface_text: planned along with his companyfederates to obtain the companytrol of the Jupiter, which at the time was in a sound financial position, by acquiring the companytrolling block of shares of the Jupiter and utilising the funds of the Jupiter itself for the acquisition of such shares.

facts.text: Agreement with Khaitan for purchase of 63,000 shares at Rs.53 per share, total Rs.33,39,000; Rs.5,39,000 cash upfront, balance Rs.28 lakhs by Jan 20, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: a bargain was settled with Khaitan for the purchase of this companytrolling block of shares at Rs. 53 per share for a sum of Rs. 33,39,000. Out of this amount a sum of Rs. 5,39,000 was to be paid over to Bajaj and Khaitan directly in cash and only Rs. 28,00,000 would be shown as the price

facts.text: Rs.4,85,000 paid to Bajaj on December 29, 1948; formal agreement dated December 29, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this agreement Rs. 4,85,000 were paid over to Bajaj on or about December 29, 1948, and a formal agreement dated December 29, 1948, was entered into, incorporating the above terms.

facts.text: On Dec 29, 1948, 1,250 qualifying shares allotted to Lala Shankarlal, Kaul, Mehta, Jhaveri, Doshi; they appointed directors.

anchor.surface_text: On that very day Bajaj and other directors of Khaitan group held a meeting and allotted 1,250 shares straightaway to Lala Shankarlal and four of his numberinees viz., Kaul, Mehta, Jhaveri and Doshi, each 250 shares, as qualifying shares for each.

facts.text: Jupiter securities sold (Rs.15 lakhs face value realized Rs.13,99,768) and overdraft Rs.14,21,812 on pledge, total Rs.28,21,580 used to pay Rs.28,15,000 for shares.

anchor.surface_text: The sale of securities realised Rs. 13,99,768 and on the pledge of securities a sum of Its. 14,21,812 was obtained, making up a total of Rs. 28,21,580. Rs. 28,15,000 out of it was shown as having been received by the Bank of India

facts.text: Camouflaged as loan Rs.25,15,000 to Caveeshar on equitable mortgage of Delhi properties and Rs.2,60,000 for Delhi Stores plots.

anchor.surface_text: At the same meeting a loan of Rs. 25,15,000 purported to have been granted to Caveeshar by way of an equitable mortgage on an alleged application by him dated January 4, 1949, relating to his properties at Delhi so- Light to be given as security

facts.text: Payment to Khaitan on January 20, 1949 via cheques from Jupiter to Tropical, totaling Rs.27,65,700 deposited.

anchor.surface_text: From January 18 to 20, 1949, five cheques were issued on the Jupiter account in the Punjab National Bank which were all deposited into the account of the Tropical in the Punjab National Bank as follows A cheque for Rs. 2,55,050, dated January 18, 1949

facts.text: Lala Shankarlal died before trial; Doshi died before trial.

anchor.surface_text: four persons, who along with one Ramniklal Keshavlal Jhaveri  since acquitted  were companymitted for trial ... of whom two Lala Shankarlal Hiralal Bansal  hereinafter referred to as Lala Shankarlal  and Saubhagyachand Umedchand Doshi  hereinafter referred to as Doshi  died before companymencement of the trial.

facts.text: Jhaveri acquitted by Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Ramniklal Keshvlal Jhaveri, accused No. 3 and since acquitted by the Sessions Judge

facts.text: Kaul barrister, in Delhi Dec 1948; Mehta manager Bombay office Tropical; Guha accountant Tropical; Caveeshar MD Peoples Insurance.

anchor.surface_text: Accused No. 1, Kaul, is a barrister and was in Lahore till the partition of the companyntry. In December, 1948, he was in Delhi. Accused No. 2 Mehta, at all material times was the manager of the Bombay Office  General  of the Tropical.

facts.text: Trial with jury; Caveeshar and Kaul by majority verdict, Mehta and Guha unanimous.

anchor.surface_text: The trial before the Sessions Judge was with the aid of a jury. All of them except Jhaveri were found guilty, appellants in Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 54, Sardul Singh Caveeshar and Parmeshwar Nath Kaul, by a majority verdict

facts.text: Bombay High Court accepted jury verdicts on Nov 21, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 21, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 861-864 of 1956

facts.text: Judgment delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J. on May 23, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. May 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-

facts.text: Subsequent manipulations in 1949 to show loans repaid: Raghavji loan, fresh Caveeshar loan, Misri Devi loan, Tropical shares purchase.

anchor.surface_text: there were brought into existence, five transactions, from May 25 to December 31, 1949, which have been referred to in the evidence as follows Rs. Raghavji loan  5-11-1949  which resulted in repayment of 4,00,000 Fresh Caveeshar loan  5-11-1949  which resulted in repayment of 5,30,000

facts.text: In 1950, further steps using Empire of India funds to camouflage 1949 transactions after auditors raised concerns.

anchor.surface_text: the background for the events of this period was-according to the prosecution-the situation that arose from the strong attitude taken by the auditors in the companyrse of their audit of the affairs of the Jupiter for the year 1949

facts.text: Auditors queried Caveeshar loan documents on Jan 6, 1950 and Feb 6, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1950, the auditors sent a letter to the Jupiter demanding inspection of the documents relating to the said loan of Caveeshar. This was followed up by a further letter dated February 6

issues.text: What is the scope for interference on appeal either by the High Court or by this Court with convictions and sentences based on the acceptance of the verdict of the jury?

anchor.surface_text: Since the appeals before the High Court and before us are against the convictions and sentences based on the acceptance of the verdict of the jury against each of the accused, scope for interference on appeal either by the High Court or by this Court is very limited.

issues.text: Whether evidence of acts, writings and statements of conspirators during the year 1950 (outside the conspiracy period) is admissible under s.10 of the Evidence Act in proof of the conspiracy or participation of individual accused therein?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari contends that on the substantive charge of conspiracy all these steps or actings are not admissible in law. Now the conspiracy as charged is in substance a conspiracy to commit criminal breach of trust... under s. 10 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 (I of 1872 ).

issues.text: Whether the evidence objected to, viz., the acts and events of the year 1950, would be relevant under the other sections of the Evidence Act such as ss. 6, 8, 9, 11 and 14?

anchor.surface_text: But his contention is that the evidence objected to, viz., the acts and events of the year 1950, would be relevant under the other sections of the Evidence Act such as ss. 6, 8, 9, 11 and 14.

issues.text: Whether such evidence (acts outside conspiracy period) is admissible in proof of the conspiracy and in proof of the participation of individual accused in the conspiracy?

anchor.surface_text: His contention raises for consideration two questions, viz., 1 whether such evidence is admissible in proof of the conspiracy and in proof of the participation of individual accused in the conspiracy, and

issues.text: Whether in fact at the trial, such evidence was admitted and made use of on the issues of proof of conspiracy and participation?

anchor.surface_text: 2 whether in fact at the trial, such evidence was admitted and made use of on these issues.

issues.text: Whether the evidence of 1950 events rebuts the defence of innocent participation by showing criminal intention under s.14 Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: Such evidence would come under s. 14 of the Evidence Act. It is well settled that the evidence in rebuttal of a very likely and probable defence on the question of intention can be led by the prosecution as part of its case.

issues.text: Whether admission of the 1950 evidence caused prejudice to the accused rendering the trial unfair?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari very strenuously contends that such evidence was inadmissible and that its admission has seriously prejudiced the case of the appellants...

arguments.claim: s.10 Evidence Act limits: evidence admissible only if done/written/spoken in carrying out conspiracy and step in its proof; in reference to common intention

anchor.surface_text: The limits of the admissibility of evidence in conspiracy cases under s. 10 of the Evidence Act have been authoritatively laid down by the Privy Council in Mirza Akbar v. The King-Emperor . In that case their Lordships of the Privy Council held that s. 10 of the Evidence Act must be construed in accordance with the principle that the thing done, written, or spoken, was something done in carrying out the conspiracy

arguments.claim: Evidence of acts outside specified conspiracy period not receivable under s.10

anchor.surface_text: It would seem to follow that where, as in this case, the charge specifies the period of conspiracy, evidence of acts of conspirators outside the period is not receivable in evidence.

arguments.claim: Evidence ss.6,8,9,11,14 widely worded, require limited construction

anchor.surface_text: This would no doubt be so. But it has to be remembered that some of these sections are widely worded and must receive a somewhat limited construction as pointed out by West J. in his judgment reported in Reg. v. Prabhudas

arguments.claim: 1950 evidence relevant to show bogus character of Jan 1949 transactions (Caveeshar loan, Delhi Stores)

anchor.surface_text: Now, there can be no doubt that one of the main relevant issues in the case is whether the loan of Rs. 25 lakhs and odd advanced on January 20, 1949, to Caveeshar, as also the moneys said to have been paid to the Delhi Stores by way of advance for purchase of certain plots said to belong to it, were genuine transactions or bogus and make-believe.

arguments.claim: 1950 transactions integrally connected to prove bogus nature of original transactions despite being beyond conspiracy period

anchor.surface_text: Thus in relation to the main purpose of the prosecution, viz., proof of the bogus character of these transactions of January, 1949, the transactions of the second half of 1949 and of 1950 must, in the circumstances of this case and having regard to the ramifications, be taken to be integrally connected and relevant to make out their bogus character.

arguments.claim: Conduct of individual conspirator outside period admissible against himself to show criminal intention, rebut innocent participation defence under s.14 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that such conduct irrespective of the time to which it relates can be relied on by the prosecution to show the criminality of the intention of the individual accused with reference to his proved participation in the alleged conspiracy, that is, to rebut a probable defence which may normally arise in such a case, viz., that the participation, though proved, was innocent.

arguments.court_reasoning: Well settled per Makin v Attorney-General; anticipate defence and prove intention beyond reasonable doubt

arguments.claim: 1950 evidence falls into two admissible categories: (1) bogus character of original transactions; (2) criminal intention of each accused

anchor.surface_text: Now Mr. Khandalawala for the prosecution urges that the entire evidence for the prosecution relating to the year 1950 falls within these two categories of admissible evidence, viz.,  1  evidence to make out the bogus character of the original transactions of January, 1949, which is an essential issue in the case relating to all the conspirators, and  2  evidence of the criminal intention of each of the accused which is admissible as against himself

arguments.claim: 1950 evidence of individual conspirators' acts used at trial to prove conspiracy existence and individual participation

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari for the appellants contests this assumption and urges that the evidence that has been admitted of the year 1950 is much wider than what is covered by the above two and that it was in fact and in substance evidence of the acts, writings and statements of individual conspirators of a period outside the period of conspiracy, and treated as admissible against other conspirators, on the central issues in the case

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari very strenuously contends that such evidence was inadmissible and that its admission has seriously prejudiced the case of the appellants and has rendered any fair and rational consideration of the case by the jury extremely difficult, if not impossible.

arguments.claim: Scope for interference with jury verdicts very limited on appeal

anchor.surface_text: Since the appeals before the High Court and before us are against the convictions and sentences based on the acceptance of the verdict of the jury against each of the accused, scope for interference on appeal either by the High Court or by this Court is very limited.

holdings.text: Scope for interference on appeal either by the High Court or by this Court with convictions and sentences based on the acceptance of the verdict of the jury is very limited.

anchor.surface_text: Since the appeals before the High Court and before us are against the convictions and sentences based on the acceptance of the verdict of the jury against each of the accused, scope for interference on appeal either by the High Court or by this Court is very limited.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeals under Art. 136 against jury-based convictions limit interference to cases of grave injustice or misdirection.

holdings.text: Where the charge specifies the period of conspiracy, evidence of acts of conspirators outside the period is not receivable under s.10 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: It would seem to follow that where, as in this case, the charge specifies the period of conspiracy, evidence of acts of conspirators outside the period is not receivable in evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Privy Council in Mirza Akbar v. King-Emperor: s.10 requires evidence in reference to common intention and as step in proof of conspiracy; outside period generally inadmissible.

holdings.text: Evidence of acts and events of 1950 relevant under ss.6,8,9,11,14 Evidence Act, subject to limited construction of widely worded sections.

anchor.surface_text: But his contention is that the evidence objected to, viz., the acts and events of the year 1950, would be relevant under the other sections of the Evidence Act such as ss. 6, 8, 9, 11 and 14. This would no doubt be so. But it has to be remembered that some of these sections are widely worded and must receive a somewhat limited construction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts relevance under other sections per West J. in Reg. v. Prabhudas, but cautions limited construction.

holdings.text: 1950 transactions integrally connected and relevant to prove bogus character of January 1949 transactions (Caveeshar loan, Delhi Stores).

anchor.surface_text: Thus in relation to the main purpose of the prosecution, viz., proof of the bogus character of these transactions of January, 1949, the transactions of the second half of 1949 and of 1950 must, in the circumstances of this case and having regard to the ramifications, be taken to be integrally connected and relevant to make out their bogus character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arising from auditors' scrutiny; necessary to show transactions were make-believe, not genuine investments.

holdings.text: Conduct of individual conspirator outside conspiracy period admissible against himself under s.14 Evidence Act to show criminal intention and rebut innocent participation defence.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that such conduct irrespective of the time to which it relates can be relied on by the prosecution to show the criminality of the intention of the individual accused with reference to his proved participation in the alleged conspiracy, that is, to rebut a probable defence which may normally arise in such a case, viz., that the participation, though proved, was innocent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled per Makin v. Attorney-General; prosecution may anticipate defence and prove intention beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.text: At trial, 1950 evidence not admitted or used for proof of conspiracy existence or individual participation, but distinguished for bogus character; trial judge properly cautioned jury on use against actor only.

anchor.surface_text: His contention raises for consideration two questions, viz., 1 whether such evidence is admissible in proof of the conspiracy and in proof of the participation of individual accused in the conspiracy, and 2 whether in fact at the trial, such evidence was admitted and made use of on these issues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of charge paras shows focus on bogus transactions; ruled out Ex Z-71; repeated cautions in paras 453 etc.; interlocutory ruling confirms distinction.

holdings.text: Admission of 1950 evidence caused no prejudice to accused; jury discriminated properly (Jhaveri acquitted).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari very strenuously contends that such evidence was inadmissible and that its admission has seriously prejudiced the case of the appellants and has rendered any fair and rational consideration of the case by the jury extremely difficult, if not impossible.... that there has in fact been any such prejudice has not been shown to our satisfaction. Indeed the fact that accused No. 3, Jhaveri, has been acquitted

holdings.reasoning_summary: No satisfaction of prejudice shown; inherent risk per Walli Muhammad insufficient without proof; acquittal shows jury caution observed.

anchor.surface_text: Mirza Akbar v. The King-Emperor  1 . In that case their Lordships of the Privy Council held that s. 10 of the Evidence Act must be companystrued in accordance with the principle that the thing done, written, or spoken, was something done in carrying out the companyspiracy and was receivable as a step in the proof of the companyspiracy. They numberice that evidence receivable under s. 10 of the Evidence Act of anything said, done, or written, by any one of such persons  i.e. companyspirators  must be in reference to their companymon intention. But their Lordships held that in the companytext  numberwithstanding the amplitude of the above phrase  the words therein are number capable of being widely companystrued having regard to the well-known principle above enunciated. It would seem to follow that where, as in this case, the charge specifies the period  1   1940  L.R. 67 I.A. 336.

precedents.cited_proposition: limits of the admissibility of evidence in companyspiracy cases under s. 10 of the Evidence Act; evidence must be in reference to companymon intention and done in carrying out the companyspiracy
precedents.cited_holding: s. 10 of the Evidence Act must be companystrued in accordance with the principle that the thing done, written, or spoken, was something done in carrying out the companyspiracy and was receivable as a step in the proof of the companyspiracy

anchor.surface_text: Reg. v. Prabhudas  1  when companysidering the scope of s. 1 1 of the Evidence Act. Now, there can be numberdoubt that one of the main relevant issues in the case is whether the loan of Rs. 25 lakhs and odd advanced on January 20, 1949, to Caveeshar, as also the moneys said to have been paid to the Delhi Stores by way of advance for purchase of certain plots said to belong to it, were genuine transactions or bogus and make-believe. If they were genuine transactions, by virtue of which money did pass to them on the basis of good security, showing these amounts to be genuine business investments, then it would be difficult to make out that there was any criminal breach of trust. Hence all evidence which would go to show that these transactions are bogus, is certainly admissible. That would be so numberwithstanding that such evidence may necessitate reference to and narration of the acts of the companyspirators beyond the period of companyspiracy but within reasonable limits. While it may be true that the manipulations by way of the four fresh transactions from May to December, 1949  apart from other features of these transactions of which evidence has been given  would be companyent evidence to show that the original transactions were bogus, the evidence relating to the further transactions to screen these transactions of the second half of 1949 by utilising the money of the Empire of India after obtaining the companytrol thereof, and by wrongfully utilising the Jupiters securities, would also be relevant to make out and emphasise the bogus character of the  1  I 874  1 1 Bom. H.C.R. 90.

precedents.citation: Makin v. The Attorney-General for New South Wales 1

anchor.surface_text: Makin v. The Attorney-General for New South Wales 1 . To anticipate a likely defence in such a case and to give evidence in rebuttal of such defence is in substance numberhing more than the letting in of evidence by the prosecution of the requisite criminal intention beyond reasonable doubt.

precedents.case_name: Makin v. The Attorney-General for New South Wales
precedents.cited_proposition: evidence in rebuttal of a very likely and probable defence on the question of intention can be led by the prosecution as part of its case under s. 14 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: Walli Muhammad v. King  1 . Therein their Lordships pointed out the difficulty in all cases where two persons are accused of a crime and where the evidence against one is inadmissible against the other. Their Lordships recognised that however carefully assessors or a jury are directed and however firmly a Judge may steel his mind against being influenced against one by the evidence admissible only against the other, nevertheless the mind may inadvertently be affected by the disclosures made by one of the accused to the detriment of the other. Undoubtedly this weighty caution has to be always kept in mind when Judges and juries. have to deal with such companyplicated cases. But that by itself without showing that serious  1   1948  53 C.W.N. 318, 321.

precedents.cited_proposition: difficulty and possibility of prejudice in joint trials where evidence against one accused is inadmissible against the other
precedents.cited_holding: however carefully assessors or a jury are directed... the mind may inadvertently be affected
